q2.description: So far we have seen a few simple machine types, such as DFA, NFA, PDA, RegEx. And we have seen corresponding grammars:
q2.question: What is the corresponding grammar for DFA, NFA, RegEx?

q3.description: So far we have seen a few simple machine types, such as DFA, NFA, PDA, RegEx. And we have seen corresponding grammars:
q3.question: What is the corresponding grammar for PDAs?

q4.description: There are some differences in the machines.
q4.question: DFAs and NFAs are exactly the same.
q4.answer: No, DFAs are deterministic. NFAs add non-determinism, which simply means that there can be multiple choices out of a state for the same input character.
choices: No, DFAs are deterministic. NFAs add non-determinism, which simply means that there can be multiple choices out of a state for the same input character.

q5.description: There are some differences in the machines.
q5.question: What are the differences between NFA and PDA
answer: PDA has a stack for storage
choices: PDA has a stack for storage

q6.description: These machines all have some similarities
q6.question: What are the similarities between NFA and PDA
answer: They all take an input string.
They all march across the string from left to right, one character at each step.
They stop when they reach the end of the string and then make a simple decision (accept/reject
choices: They all take an input string.
They all march across the string from left to right, one character at each step.
They stop when they reach the end of the string and then make a simple decision (accept/reject

q7.description: There are some differences in the machines.
q7.question: NFA and PDA are callecd acceptors
q7.answer: Yes, all that they can do is determine if a string is a member of the language, and the “more powerful” machines can accept or reject string from more “complicated” languages.
choices: Yes, all that they can do is determine if a string is a member of the language, and the “more powerful” machines can accept or reject string from more “complicated” languages.

q8.description: But there is a lot more that we typically expect when we talk about “computation”. Like, the ability to “compute” rather than simply accept.
q8.question: Suppose that $L$ is the language of all arithmatic expressions, the input for our machine is the string $2 + 3$, which of the following is a computation?
choices: accepting the string $2 + 3$ as it is $\in L$

q13.description: $\textbf{State machines}$ are simple to understand. There are a number of different state machines, with a range of capabilities. We will discuss a particular one, called a $\textbf{Turing machine}$. As we define "capability", the key is ability, not efficiency.
q13.question: Which of the following means ability of the machine
choices: consume small amount of memory as possible

q14.description:
The necessary capabilities for any such "machine" are these:
- Read
- Write
- Compute
q14.question: What is the cabability of NFAs, DFAs, and PDAs

q15.description: A Turing machine is defined as follows. It has a one-dimensional tape, divided into squares. This tape extends infinitely to the left and to the right.
q15.question: How many squares does the tape on the left have?

q16.description:
A Turing machine is defined as follows. It has a one-dimensional tape, divided into squares. This tape extends infinitely to the left and to the right.
Each square can store one character.
q16.question: How many squares are requiered to store the string $aaaa$ on the tape on the left?

Each square can store one character.
q20.question: The remaining squares will be marked blank by using the # symbol

q22.description:
A Turing machine is defined as follows. It has a one-dimensional tape, divided into squares. This tape extends infinitely to the left and to the right.
Each square can store one character.
The machine has a single I/O head that at any instant in time is "on" one of the squares.
The control unit of the machine is defined by a set of abstract $states$.
q22.question: Suppose the TM on the left, how many states the TM have?

q23.description:
A Turing machine is defined as follows. It has a one-dimensional tape, divided into squares. This tape extends infinitely to the left and to the right.
Each square can store one character.
The machine has a single I/O head that at any instant in time is "on" one of the squares.
The control unit of the machine is defined by a set of abstract $states$.
At any given instant, the machine is said to be "in" one of the states, and has a set of actions that can be performed when in that state.
q23.question: In which state the machie is now?

q24.description:
It is worth to note that once the TM starts, the tape head will start at the leftmost non-blank tape cell.
From the current state, the machine will read the symbol on the current square
q24.question: The machine head will start at index 1 and will read the current cell letter: $a$

q25.description:
From the current state, the machine will read the symbol on the current square, and will then do the following (depending on the value of the symbol that it sees):
1. Overwrite that symbol with a new symbol,
2. Move the tape head either left (L), right (R), or stay (S)
q25.question: In TM tape, the # symbole means empty cell, or erase the current cell. Based on the current trasition, what will be the new value for the current tape cell?

q26.description:
From the current state, the machine will read the symbol on the current square, and will then do the following (depending on the value of the symbol that it sees):
1. Overwrite that symbol with a new symbol,
2. Move the tape head either left (L), right (R), or stay (S)
q26.question: Based on the current trasition, what will be the head movement direction?
q26.answer: R: go to the cell on the right
choices: R: go to the cell on the right
L: go to the cell on the left
S: stay on the current cell

q27.description:
From the current state, the machine will read the symbol on the current square, and will then do the following (depending on the value of the symbol that it sees):
1. Overwrite that symbol with a new symbol,
2. Move the tape head either left (L), right (R), or stay (S)
q27.question: Based on the current trasition, what will happen to the tape and the head?
q27.answer: erase the current letter and go to the cell on the right
choices: erase the current letter and go to the cell on the right
leave the current letter and go to the cell on the right
erase the current letter and go to the cell on the left
leave the current letter and go to the cell on the left
erase the current letter and stay at the current cell
leave the current letter and stay at the current cell

q39.description: A Turing machine is $\textbf{formally defined}$ as $(Q, \Sigma, \Gamma, q_0, F, \delta)$.

Move the head after writing the letter

q50.description:
Here is an example of a machine that is slightly more complicated. This Turing machine accepts the language $L(a^*b^*c^*)$

$M = (Q, Σ, Γ, s, F, δ)$
• $Q = \{q_0, q_1, q_2, q_3\}$,
• $Σ = \{a, b, c\}$,
• $Γ = Σ ∪ \{\#\} $,
• $s = q_0$,
• $F = q_2$,
• $δ = $
         ---------------------------------
          $q$     $Γ$     $(q, Γ, \{L, R, S\})$
         ---------------------------------
          $q_0$   $a$      $(q_0, a, R)$
          $q_0$   $b$      $(q_1, b, R)$
          $q_0$   $c$      $(q_2, c, R)$
          $q_0$   $\#$     $(q_3, \#, S)$
          $q_1$   $b$      $(q_1, b, R)$
          $q_1$   $c$      $(q_2, c, R)$
          $q_1$   $\#$     $(q_3, \#, S)$
          $q_2$   $c$      $(q_2, c, R)$
          $q_2$   $\#$     $(q_3, \#, S)$
q50.question: What is the type of this language?

q51.description:
Here is an example of a machine that is slightly more complicated. This Turing machine accepts the language $L(a^*b^*c^*)$

$M = (Q, Σ, Γ, s, F, δ)$
• $Q = \{q_0, q_1, q_2, q_3\}$,
• $Σ = \{a, b, c\}$,
• $Γ = Σ ∪ \{\#\} $,
• $s = q_0$,
• $F = q_2$,
• $δ = $
         ---------------------------------
          $q$     $Γ$     $(q, Γ, \{L, R, S\})$
         ---------------------------------
          $q_0$   $a$      $(q_0, a, R)$
          $q_0$   $b$      $(q_1, b, R)$
          $q_0$   $c$      $(q_2, c, R)$
          $q_0$   $\#$     $(q_3, \#, S)$
          $q_1$   $b$      $(q_1, b, R)$
          $q_1$   $c$      $(q_2, c, R)$
          $q_1$   $\#$     $(q_3, \#, S)$
          $q_2$   $c$      $(q_2, c, R)$
          $q_2$   $\#$     $(q_3, \#, S)$
q51.question: Does the machine change the tape content while processing language strings?
